text: Bottle. Pours black with a light brown head that dissipates to the edges. Aroma has a strong coffee note with roasted malts and dark grains supporting. Flavor has a rich coffee throughout with earthy dark grains and a growing roasted malt presence.

Bottle. Black with a tan head. Huge roasty coffee aroma, milk, chocolate malted milk balls and light earthiness. Taste is fairly sweet with a light dry dark chocolate and coffee finish. Medium body with a creamy feel. Good balance of coffee in flavor and aroma.
Bottle. Black with light tan head. Bitter toasty coffee, some dark fruit in the aroma as well. Flavor is rich iced coffee, some burlap, light oat, burnt toast finish. Medium body. Good

Coffee Stout is another prime example that Sierra Nevada is fully capable of brewing a Stout. Full bodied roasted malt, moderate bitterness and strong coffee flavors. A delicious part of a mixed 12-pack.

From Snow Pack mix. Brown, nearly black. Tan head. Burnt roast nose. Roast then coffee bean profile. That burnt flavor finishes with little in between. There is some sweet malt and palate is generously coated. Still not a huge fan of the coffee brews.
[1/28/17] Bottle at the AirBnB apartment in Santa Rosa. Black. Lots of coffee, slightly vegetal, roast, some cocoa. Sweet flavor, bitterish finish. Good.

Pours a very dark brown color, not quite black. Has a super huge head, about three fingers or more. Super good retention, excellent lacing. As I poured, this huge head was swirling and everything, and it looked it had some black sediment swirling around, and I thought it looked like chocolate sprinkles. Wow!!Aroma is well, coffee. Coffee, coffee and baking chocolate. Coffee strong. Baking chocolate medium. Dark fruits are light. Theres some medium dark roasted malt in there too.Taste is much the same. Lots of chocolate!ate, some chocolate and a little, barely noticeable dark fruit. Very coffe, but also very sweet.Mouthfeel is medium bodied at best. Its a little watery, it could stand to be a tad heavier. Smart business move, because if it were heavier, it would be perfect, and our quest for great beer would be over. But theres a little bit of sediment, like coffee grit in there. Overall, this is great! Almost perfect. Maybe Im partial, because I love coffee so much. But I call em like I see em. This is a great beer. No! I dont recommend this (more for me) and yes, I would buy it again!! Well done!!

Love it!! Thick and full of flavor! You get coffee hints but its not overwhelming at all, very balanced beer

(12oz bottle) AROMA: coffee, mocha, sweet, creamy APPEARANCE: dark dark, tan creamy head TASTE: coffee, sweet, toasted malt, tobacco, smoke, some herb/medicine PALATE: soft, medium/full body, creamy, decent bitterness. OVERALL: big coffee. very nice stout. Coffee dominates, soft and smooth. balanced and enjoyable. Did I mention coffee.
Great all around stout. The coffee elevates the whole package with a nice nose and waves of coffee and dark chocolate notes. My go to beer this winter.

Bottle. Poured clear dark brown color with an average tan frothy head that mostly lasted with very good lacing. Moderate ground coffee and dark chocolate aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and flat carbonation. Medium to heavy roasted coffee dark sweet flavor with a medium dark sweet finish of moderate duration. This beer

Pours dark brown with tan head. Aroma is deep and dark chocolate mocha. Flavor is smooth and nutty with smoky chocolate finish.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2017 Lots of coffee taste to this one very nice little light for a stout and a little low on the alcohol content. Got this in a seasonal 12 pk . Definitely worth a try.

12 ounce bottle Perhaps the best coffee stout that I have ever had. I would love to come upon a pub some winters night that would have this on tap. That would be wonderful, Outstanding taste, mouth feel, look and aroma.

Hmm well this was an interesting seasonal novelty, from the bottle pours with a strong flavorful sweet coffee and roasty aroma, with notes of chocolate. Great appearance of charred black with a ruby highlight, full off-white head with Guinness-like lacing. Flavor is lightly roasted malt, espresso, milk chocolate, cocoa, hint of licorice. I dont mind its contribution to the flavor, but I dislike the coffee infusions impact on the palate and mouthfeel, seems to have thinned out and watered down the texture, finishes just as if finishing a sip of iced coffee. Perhaps just utilizing coffee bean in the brew instead of already brewed coffee may avoid that issue. Either way its not bad, but if I want to drink coffee Ill actually get a coffee instead of mixing it with my beer.

Part of winter "Snowpack". Pours dark brown. Excellent nose of chocolate and coffee. Taste doesn't live up to the nosy - there is some coffee, black licorice, but I found the finish a bit thin. Ok, but not great.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2017 On draught at the Mills River brewery. Brown-black color with a medium thick foamy beige head that recedes gradually to a film. Small patches of lacing on the glass. Roasted coffee, malt and chocolate aroma. Medium body with a roasty coffee and malt character, with bittersweet chocolate in the background. The finish is mildly bitter roasted coffee. Pretty good overall.

Bottle.

A: Pitch black with a mocha head. Lacing.

N: Coffee, cocoa, earth, some vanilla, hint of molasses, plenty of spice and peppercorn. Hint of cherry. Ash and roast. Burnt biscuit. 

T: Quite bitter. Roasty and lightly sweet.

M: Medium body, no alcohol, spritzy carbonation.

O: Very nice. Just an all around solid stout with coffee.

12 oz. bottle from the Sno Pack 12 pack from Market Basket. Reasonably priced at $11.99 (on sale). Poured dark brown, black into a snifter. Gentle pours nets a one finger bubbly beige head with no lace to speak of. Coffee forward nose with some dark chocolate. Flavor is also mostly coffee with cream. Hints of caramel and chocolate show themselves on the swallow. Modest body. Pretty darn good!

Pitch black tar-like pour, medium thick mocha colored head that hangs around a while. Aroma has a solid roasted espresso bent to it, some creosote. Smooth, bold roasted coffee flavor, hints of bittersweet bakers chocolate. Nice chalky mouthfeel. Thanks to Aurelius for holding this out from his variety pack!
Pours a black from a bottle with a brown head. Coffee aroma doesnt really follow through in the flavor, where chocolate is more dominant. Pretty good beer.
12 ounce bottle. Pours a clear pitch black color with a medium beige head. A huge coffee nose. The flavor is big sweet coffee, vanilla, light roast, chocolate. Pretty good.

The best part of the Snow Pack variety release. Opaque black color with a sizable head of khaki colored foam. Smooth mild roast coffee on the aroma and pallette set against a well-balanced caramel malt base.

Nothing new or crazy going on here but a solid beer nontheless. Aroma has coffee, but not as much as some coffee beers. More coffee in the flavor as well as sweet malt, and this beer is sweet. A little chocolate. Surprised it is rated as high as it is, but nothing wrong with it.

Draft at Sierra Nevada NC. Pours black with a thin khaki head. Leaves some lacing in the glass. Has some solid coffee notes on the nose. Lots of coffee bitterness on the tongue which plays well with all the roasted malt. Finished clean. Solid example of a coffee stout.

Poured from bottle thanks Airforcehops 9/20/16 light cola.brown with a mocha head. Aromas of coffee roasted malt chocolate grain. Taste is smooth coffee chocolate malt toffee with a medium thin mouth feel.

Rich, opaque brown black. Squat 12-ozer. Bad label. Khaki head. Nice, mellow coffee aroma. Sturdy, but not overpowering java. Sugary at times, but not overly sweet. Toasted, roasted, a little bakers chocolate. Very mellow and definitely winter comfort on an icy (54°) north Florida night. Very nice. Publix, Bradfordville.

Medium brown pour, black in the glass with a small, tan head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, toffee, caramel, and a little more coffee. Nice mix of whole bean and brewed coffee aromas. A little bit of burnt malt and caramel is also noticeable, but blends right in the abundant coffee. Super smooth texture gives way to smooth coffee and muted stout notes. Really nice balance.

Poured from a 12 OZ bottle into a pint glass. The appearance is a very dark black with a dense large brown head. The aroma is coffee, malt and chocolate. The taste matches the nose but the semi-sweet chocolate is a bit more pronounced.

12 ounce bottle poured to wine glass	
black, opaque, small brown foam
fragrant, toasted nuts, coffee does not overpower	
low bitterness, some sweetness	
lively carbonation, long follow through	
very good beer ok to repeat, look for maybe
drank: December 9, 2016 7:03 PM

From the mixed 12 pack from Market Basket.
Solid dark brown black with a frothy tan head that persists. Huge coffee on the nose with bits of roast grains earth and light chocolate. Big coffee flavor with roasty caramel hiding underneath. Smooth creamy coffee bomb, pretty tasty beer.

It pours quite dark with a tan head. The aroma has cream, coffee, vanilla and dark chocolate. It has a medium body with semi sharp carbonation. The taste has heavy roast, coffee, bitterness and unsweetened chocolate. Good.

355ml bottle. As "Cold brew" coffee stout. Black-brown pour. Long lasting tan/off white head. Aroma is coffee and stout. No green pepper like some coffee stouts. Flavor is the same, just a velvety cocoa/coffee/ roasted malt combo. Divine.
A dark, rich, but not overly heavy stout. Came as part of the winter variety pack.
Bottle. Pours a black color with beige head. Roasty, freshly brewed coffee, malty, slight cream aromas. Fresh coffee, roasty, slight bitter, slight creamy flavors.
12oz bottle pours a muddy brown/black with some fluffy, off white head. Nose of toast, malt, chocolate, coffee. Flavor follows, coffee, caramel, chewy grains. Dry finish. Straight up.

I love coffee, so I was looking forward to this one. pours jet black, totally opaque, with a good half inch of a cappuccino colored thick head that stays. aroma is what youd expect, dark roasted malts and french dark roast fresh brewed coffee with some spicy notes. this is a full bodied beer, with creamy texture, lively carbonation and just a slight astringency. the taste follows the aroma. dark roasted malts, combined with fresh brewed coffee (I do not detect cocoa/chocolate) perfectly balanced by the hop bitterness, which makes this a really easy drinking stout. finishes short and dry. for me, not a huge stout drinker, outstanding!

poured a medium brown from the bottle to the snifter, long lasting tan head and decent lacing. the aroma is a medium roasted malt with a very nice coffee scent. I dont drink coffee but I love the aroma of this one. the flavor again holds true medium malt and enough coffee to give this an excellent flavor. not real bitterness from the coffee or the hops in this one..

Tasted from bottle. Pours very dark brown with thick khaki head. Huge coffee aroma with some cocoa. Taste is well balanced with flavors of coffee, cocoa, vanilla, brown sugar. Very well done.

Deep brown pour with little head. Strong aroma of cold brew coffee and roasted malts. Taste of milk, gentle dark chocolate, coffee flavor is more of an accent than in the aroma, and robust roasted malts. Creamy mouthfeel thats almost nitro like, medium to full bodied with moderate finish that ends with slight coffee/dark chocolate bitterness. This is very nice.
Bottle from Albertsons. Rich roasty sweetness up front. Milk sugar and coffee. Good and rich. Tastes like a sweet iced coffee. Roasty with a touch up hop bitterness in the finish. Easy sipper.
On Tap Nearly black, tan head and lacing. Very nice combination of coffee and dark roast barley. Creamy palate, and pleasantly bitter coffee trailer. Excellent coffee stout.

Pours black with a one finger tan head with good lacing. Aroma is of cold brew coffee, roasted malts, dark chocolate, sweet malts, caramel, and some brown sugar notes. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a semi creamy mouthfeel and a slightly bitter, medium-long finish. Overall, a tasty coffee stout that features cold brew coffee nicely.

Black with fast fading head and a wonderful coffee aroma. Taste is coffee, roasted malts, and cola. Little flat feeling and the aftertaste is more of that cola thing. Its not bad but the mild hints of cola are just not doing it for me. Got this in sampler last year and again this year and wont be disappointed to get it again in years to come.

A very delicious and full flavored stout. Aroma was big and rich. Dark roasted coffee and heavily roasted malt. Pour was a deep dark brown/near black with a one finger tan head. Taste was roasty and big. Strong biting dark roasted coffee beans with slight hints of dark chocolate. Bitter roasted (almost burnt) bitter malt finish. A little hop bite after the swallow thst played well with the bitter malt flavors. Nice carbonation.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Bottle from the winter snow pack. Color is a deep brown/ damn near black, thin lasting tan head that stayed the whole way down. Aroma is bold coffee, mild roast, and a mild nutty hint. 
Gosh, this is nice. The coffee is balanced by a light bitterness, roasted grain, nutty earthy hints. Mouthfeel is smooth /creamy, yet a tad lean for a stout. Body could use some beefing up. Still, if this was sold stand alone in a 6 pack, I would buy more. And that statement is huge since I am mostly a ticker.
Aromas of fresh brewed coffee hints of chocolate and faint dark fruit. Rich flavor of coffee bitter chocolate. Thick and chewy on the palate, with a decent carbonation bite.

Model from mix pack. Pours black with a small tan head. Heavy aroma of coffee, yummy dark roast coffee. Taste is creamy bitter dark roast coffee, chocolate Malta, and leaves. Nice.

Pours a finger of head on a dark brown body. Aroma is coffee, chocolate, milk and black malt. Taste is black coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malt. Texture is crisp with soft edges.

Bottle.

A- Black coffee, roasty, subtle dark fruit, earthy, burnt caramel, molasses.

A- Black color, black liquid, tan head.

T- Roasty, dry, cocoa, slightly bitter, coffee, dark fruits.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, roasted bitter finish.

O- I enjoy coffee stouts a lot but I thought in typical SN fashion this would showcase the bitter side of coffee. In instead showed of the earthy fruity side and did it without being too bitter or sweet. Lots of natural black coffee in here, no bs. Just a tad thin on the body otherwise this would be a near perfect stout.

Poured from bottle given by dave...black pour with light creamy head...nose is all coffee...mouth is coffee but it is light...this beer has a creaminess to it...very light berries in the distance....finish has a little bitterness to it...quality example of this style.
Pours black with tan head. Aromas of coffee and roasted malt. Coffee and slightly bitter roasted malt with a hint of chocolate. Medium to full body with moderate carbonation and a ashy finish.

Bottle pour into nonic pint glass from Smileys Discount Beverage. Appearance is dark brown with slight mahogany with light source directly behind--virtually opaque--with small sparkle, 2-finger width foamy light brown head with good retention and nice sudsy lacing. Aroma is roasted malts and coffee, dark fruits and dark chocolate, caramel and vanilla. Taste is mix of sweet malts, dark fruit, and chocolate with bitter balance from coffee and roasted malts. Palate is full bodied with thick texture, lively carbonation and bitter dominant though mixed sweet/bitter finish. Overall, this one is true to the description and fires on all cylinders.

Bottled. 09/15. Pours black, effervescent, tan head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt. Flavor is similar. Lots of coffee. Roasted malt. Nice. Nothing exceptional. But as. Promised. Good quality from Sierra Nevada.
Pours blackish with brown edges, cappuccino head, lace. Malty coffee aroma. More of the same on the tongue...just a lot of coffee, not much more for me.

Poured from a bottle. Dark opaque mahogany brown to black that has a slight vanilla tan head that starts off healthy and thins out quickly, but leaves nice lacing. Good dark fruit and toffee notes in the aroma and flavor that balance well with the roast of the malt. When beer and coffee dance back and forth without one outshining the other, I think this is when a coffee beer succeeds.

Black like coffee and with coffee head. Aroma says coffee and roasted malts; Flavours that dominate the taste as well, with some vanilla. Well balanced sweet and bitter and very creamy and smooth. excellent stout!

Pour out of 12 oz bottle, dark black pour with tan head, aroma brought notes of nice roast, coffee, espresso, hints of dark fruit into dark chocolate, dark fruit, hints of molasses, caramel, slight spice notes. Taste was a mix of iced coffee, roast, caramel, toffee into cocoa, slight spice, vanilla, finishing fairly bitter.
(bottle) clear very dark brown colour with a medium tall brown head; aroma of coffee, dark chocolate, roast; nice, balanced flavour with a long, light bitter finish; very nice

UPDATED: NOV 21, 2016 Sampled on draft at Pipers Pub this beer poured a black color with a large fluffy brown head that lingered and left excellent lacing. The aroma was faint chocolate and roasty malts with a moderate floral hop presence. The flavor was bitter and roasty with light notes of chocolate, coffee and vanilla followed by sharp floral hops.  Medium length finish. Medium body and fairly smooth. Solid
Bottle: Poured a caramel brown with orange edges, the head was bubble tan. Aroma sweet malt, coffee and licorice. Taste is similar with coffee, dark chocolate and roasted malts.

Poured from the bottle into a pint glass to drink. The beer had a wet, black pour and color with a good-sized creamy and foamy tan head with very good retention, cling, and lacing. Its aroma featured roasty malty tones, especially caramel, coffee, and toffee along with hints of chocolate and fruit, and some light earthy hops and bread scents. The beer had a somewhat sweet roasty coffee taste with hints of chocolate and caramel, along with a modest bitter component featuring bread and grain. It was a fairly wet and smooth beer with average carbonation and life, and a silky, clean mouthfeel.
Strong aromas of coffee, caramel, and cocoa. Black with a fully lasting beige head. Roasty, well balanced. Medium-full bodied, very smooth.

A hard nib. Sweet coffee darkness. Bitter astringent but strong profile. Good to the last drop. Enjoyable. Bitterness. Ground black coffee sweet taste.

pours pitch black with a medium brown head. aroma is toasted malt and coffee. creamy mouth feel. taste is burnt toast and black coffee. long warming black coffee finish. delightful on a cold winter night.
12oz bottle. Poured a black color with a tan head. Coffee, roast, and some lighter earthiness.

Bottle from the Winter Mix Pack. Pours a deep stout brown with an off-tan head. Nose is a nice burst of roasted coffee with some chocolate and sweet caramel. Flavor starts with coffee then goes to roast, some mild bitterness, and hints of chocolate. Light to medium in body and a very enjoyable beer.
Smell of strong black cofee. Not much head, no lacing. . Dark brown. Dark coffee taste with some bitterness. Smooth texture.. Somewhat bubbly
New Years Day. After a big breakfast this is my dessert. Smells of coffee and cream. Light carbonation, taste dominated by coffee but get some chocolate and cream in the taste also.
12 oz bottle out of the Snow Pack. Pours black with a khaki head. Aroma and taste are about what you expect, coffee, chocolate and some fruit as well. Overall a nice stout.
Bottle - Pours a very dark brown with a creamy head. Aroma s=is straight up coffee and dark malts. Nice body, some sweet chocolate and then some bitter coffee notes. Very good brew.

Deep dark brown with ruby highlights. Light brown head. Excellent cold brew coffee aroma (no harshness). Chocolate accompanying. Flavor follows, but less bold. Finishes with smooth coffee, light roastiness, mild bitterness. Light body. Coffee showcased and still well integrated. Nice.
Sweet coffee and cream aroma. Taste follows suit along with a strong chocolate affect. Smooth and great! ??
Bottle from a sampler. Pours black with some tan head. Aroma is bitter chocolate, coffee. Taste is off. Stale coffee, dry and bitter. Ashes, burnt toast. Meh.

12 oz bottle from Food Lion, Short Pump, VA The stout poured a deep black with 1/2 inch head of tan foamy head. Coffee is first aroma that greets you, but it is not overpowering like some stouts. The stout taste is wonderful with bittersweet chocolate and coffee. The creamy stout has a medium body with soft carbonation. The finish has some burnt malt on the tip of the tongue with some acidity.

Poured from bottle. Aroma of coffee ice cream - Good. Stout black with coarse lacing tan head. Tasting coffee, caramel, creamy malt, dry cocoa, licorice, hops. Very well balanced - highly drinkable for a coffee stout. Lots of flavor without being overwhelming. Well done.

text: 12 FL OZ ($14.99 Assorted 12 pack) pretty good stout. very few companys in the USA can do a stout. this is pretty good. has the smokey characters and is well rounded with coffee malts. liked it.
12oz bottle - roast and lactose nose. Sip is quite similar. Complex dark chocolate bitterness with slight sweetness. Cant believe Ive never had this yet.

Via the winter 12 pack. Pours beautifully with a picture perfect half inch burnt umber head. Nose of toasted dark malt. Enlivening biting body with some astringency. Milk chocolate and heavy cocoa enliven and balance the ring of coffee bitterness. Yummy.
Bottle. Pours black with a generous creamy beige head. Aroma of rich chocolate malt and coffee beans. Roasty chocolate malt and coffee flavor. Full bodied and quite good.

Pours deep, warm coffee sable with a thick and rather persistent tan head. Cant beat that with a baseball bat. Roast malt aroma presents an overtone of quality coffee, as well as earthy, smoky, and subtle molasses and dark fruit notes. Flavor echoes all these, and though coffee is still dominant, it gladly shares the tongues attention with all the others. Body seems thin for a stout, but fizz is strong and persistent. Perfect for Turkey Day.
great coffee flavor; great aroma of roasting beans. Flavor is rich and enjoyable without being overwhelming
12 ounce in mixed 12 pack. Good coffee flavor, moderate body and roast. Well balanced, very well, nothing jumps out at you, but very nicely crafted. As expected.
Dark brown, small dense brown head, good lacing. Coffee aroma. Roasty. Taste is black coffee, dark cocoa, roast, slight sweetness, mild bitterness . Not bad.
Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a glass. Black with small light brown head. Aroma is coffee, medium body, medium carbonation, and good small-bubble lacing. Taste is bitter coffee.

Bottle. Nice. Aromatice of mocha and cocoa. Taste is wonderfully complex with mocha, dark chocolates, bitter black walnuts and coffee. Palate is a tad oily but otherwise good for the style. Finishes long. Nice, very nice.
Roasted coffee flavor with a milky finish that is slightly bitter a little acidic and surprisingly not hoppy like other Sierra Nevada offerings.

Bottle. Dark brown with a frothy tan head that slowly dissipates leaving ample lacing. The Aroma is malty roasted coffee and chocolate. The flavor is the same along with burnt toast and some caramel. It has a medium bitterness to it up front but finishes with some sugary sweetness.

Pours dark brown and kissed red in the light with a fat foamy brown sugar head. Aroma is roasted malt and coffee with some notes of bakers chocolate. Taste is rich roasted malts and expresso. Some cocoa and dark fruit notes as well. Fairly bitter roastiness - or is that hops? Excellent coffee stout that is just full of flavor. Enjoyed.

Sampled November 2014
A steady pour produces a fat-two-finger thick, nicely brown-stained, dark tan colored head. The beer is a dark chocolate color. The aroma has smooth notes of roasted coffee to it even as I am pouring it. A more focused look at the nose yields a bit sharper, more burnt, and even a touch acrid, roasted coffee character. Burnt berry notes (typical of coffee), dark chocolate, well charred wood, smooth roasted coffee, burnt black pepper, and a smooth, dark / roasted malt character that adds lots of toasted / roasted whole grain.

Smooth and a bit silky textured up front, it quickly picks up an effervescent, prickly carbonation and the roast character cleans the palate quite well towards the finish. Fairly dry tasting with all of the dark malt, and burnt coffee notes, there is a touch of rounded, toasted, whole-grain maltiness that isnt quite sweet, but leans towards that and adds a touch of richness to the beer. The roast character, between the dark grain and coffee addition, is easily the most dominant part of the flavor profile; lots of acrid, bitter, burnt, roasted character is contributed by the coffee, and supported by the dark malt.

Definitely a Coffee Stout, it could use some more malt richness to balance things out here

On tap at bier thirty. Pours out black topped with a tan head. Nose is full on roast coffee beans heavy malts and a little green hop. Taste is dominated by the coffee with a little acidic bitterness on the end.

355ml bottle bought at Q-Club in SoHo, Central.
Looks: Clear deep Cola blackish brown colour with thin bits of yeast sediments; Half finger head and beige foam which fades in 30 seconds; Beautiful sticky lacing and zero carbonation.

Aroma: Very fragrant, subtle nut-roasted dark malt, with strong rich cocoa, strong caramel, vanilla, sweet toffee, iced coffee, strong cream, sugar, yeast and thin lemon.

Taste: Mid to strong sweet dark malt, with strong roastyness, fairly strong tartness, strong nuts, strong cocoa powder, black coffee, burnt toast, caramel, sugar, fairly strong resin, yeast, strong lemon, strong bitter hops and strawy grass.

Body: Medium body. Thick and creamy palate.

Mouth Feel: Strong dark maltyness in a fairly wholesome body despite strong wheaty tartness. Roastyness is as goos as its aroma, solid and very roasted peanut-like. Then its a flush of cocoa-powder, burnt toast, black coffee, sugar with strong resin ooze whicjh ended in strong and nice lemony grassy hops. Complex and comfy!

Hoppiness: Thin lemon in nose. Potent resin, strong lemon and strong strawy grass in taste. Bitterness is mid-to-strong and tasty for a lasting, mid-bitter chocolate-malty finish.

After Taste: Quite dry. Cocoa-rich and roasty bitter to mouth.

Comments: This one is more like a chocolate stout than coffee, with complex and subtle nutty roast, cocoa powder, toast, and resiny hops all folded into one nice drinking experience. Great for Summer, and just about any day in the year. Cheers!

Bottle. About 8-9 months old at consumption. Pours deep brown with an off white head. Roasted coffee sweetness up front, some dark malty notes, roasted malts, and faint lingering coffee with just a bit of bitterness. Decent.

A 12 fl oz bottle with a packaged date of 28th October 2014, and poured into a snifter glass. It poured opaque black with a nice one finger light mocha coloured head that dissipated in about 2 minutes leaving nice spotty lacing. Strong vanilla aromas with dark chocolate, roasted malts and coffee. Tastes of dark bittersweet chocolate, roasted malts, coffee and some light caramel. Medium bodied, mild but prickly carbonation, creamy and smooth. Overall, this bottle was less than 8 months old and Im thinking the coffee in it may already be less pronounced. The problem is that its not that easy for me to find it fresh in Hong Kong. It doesnt have the crisp fresh coffee bean bite like that of Founders Breakfast Stout that I really enjoy. Having said that, if I could find it again (fresher of course) then I would be sure to give it another shot.

Another great beer from Sierra Nevada. Beer pours very dark brown color with a retained tan colored head. Aromas of coffee, chocolate and toast. Taste is a wonderful amalgam of sweet and bitter. A truly wonderful beef from one of the most accessable breweries in the country.

12 ounce bottle from Hayduke that we had together via facebook chat. This is a nose full of coffee. The beer is black and sports a big tan head. A little chocolate in there, too. The first sip brings more of the chocolate than coffee. There is definitely coffee in this beer, though. It is very smooth and rich. Some dankness here. Also something fruity and grassy. Applesauce, too?! Really big malts in here. This is a malt bomb. Perhaps some of the coffee has faded here but those malts are just monstrous. Despite that this is a dry beer and it gets more so as it warms. It also gets a little syrupy and some herbal, minty, and earthy notes pop up. The finish was very earthy.

Draft. Poured near black with a sticky beige head. The aroma picked up lots of sweet roasty coffee, and thats all it needed. The flavor found similar, with lots or roasty coffee and a little cocoa.. some fresh herbal accents.. finished coffee-ee and roasty. Medium-bodied, dry, and roasty.. good balance.
Dark lack in color, good flavor nice easy drinking coffee stout. I was very happy drinking this beer.

I dont know, man, it seems a little bit thin to me, is all Im saying. Sure there is plenty of good coffee in there, but it probably needs chocolate or something else in the mix (not getting a whole lot of that, or caramel either)... but Id definitely try one again in the future. A good effort.

Black pour with a generous foamy beige head. Nice roasty nose with a bit of earthy charred coffee and a touch of black malt. Wonderful flavor of dark roast malt and a little maple and a little molasses, with a bit of earthy coffee in the background. A bit earthy sweet (licorice, maple and molasses?) and just not quite enough coffee, but its all in there in a robust sticky sweet body

Bottle - thanks Brian! Pours deep ruby black, medium brown head, dissipates fairly slowly, nice lacing. Aroma is coffee, roasted malts, some ashtray. Flavor is light sweet, light bitter, roasted malts and coffee. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Solid.

Pours with a block body and small, tan coloured head. Aroma is not very strong, some roasted malts and coffee flavours. Taste is surprisingly strong after the mild aroma. Heavy coffee taste, nice roastiness and nice bitter bite. Mouthfeel is silky smooth due to nice amount of bubbles. Nice beer if youre into coffee.

12 oz 2014 bottle.

A  Black with a generous and durable tan head. Good lacing. 

Aroma  Strong, fresh, roasted coffee nearly balanced by dark roasted grains. Dark chocolate with faint spicy hops. 

T  More bitter than the aroma suggests with nearly as much as bitterness as black coffee. Some hop bitterness as well. Very dark roasted grains with some burnt toast and dark chocolate notes. Bitter coffee and very dark roased grains linger on in the aftertaste.

Feel  Excellent. Medium-full body is creamy smooth. Soft, medium carbonation. 

O  Mostly excellent but a shade too bitter.

Opaque brown-black, sudsy tan head with big bubbles. Smells of strong coffee, roasted malt, deep coffee bitterness. Taste is roasted malt, lemon, burnt coffee beans, Body is crisp, not overly heavy, bitter, dry and slightly fluffy finish. Great beer.

Bottle from QClub at home. Dark black pour with tan bubbly head (frog eyes). Aroma is strong coffee grounds bitterness - nice. Taste follows. Really big coffee flavor. Pleasing bitterness, which lingers. Lasting coffee taste too. Exceeds expectations. Surprisingly big for a relatively low ABV. Smooth palate too. Yum.

12oz bottle. Medium tan head atop cola black body. Aroma is moderately sweet, coffee, roast, some bittersweet chocolate, light earthy. Taste is medium sweet, coffee, roast, coffee bitterness, light grapefruit/earthy. Creamy medium body, light effervescence, acidity.
A very nice coffee stout with almost the right amount of coffee. Some chocolate in there as well. Good medium mouthfeel. Just a bit more chocolate would make this really great.
Bottled, dark velvety brown color with cocoa foam, coffee bean, chocolate aroma and flavor,, some dry bitter chocolate , good body and finish

Nothing amazing but it does everything well. Excellent aromas of roasted coffee, dark chocolate and caramel. Flavors are more of the same along with some vanilla. Looks perfect with a big frothy tan head. Body was a little thin. Finishes bitter.

BOD 210/14. Pours pitch black. Outstanding head volume, World Class retention and lacing.

Nice nose of coffee and dark chocolate with notes of roast and hops.

Heavy medium body with a nice smooth texture that approaches creamy. Above normal carbonation with a touch of effervescence in the middle and a nice burst in the finish.

The flavor profile is quite nice and is intense, slightly complex and somewhat balanced, although coffee dominates. It begins with a blend of coffee and dark chocolate that slowly allows detection of the chocolate. The middle has a subtle caramel note under the coffee. A mild roast/hop bitterness is also present in the middle. The finish is slightly sweet then fades into a lingering coffee flavor that is somewhat stale.

Pours a dark dark brown color with a thick nice and fluffy mocha colored head. A fresh coffee bean aroma with cocoa. A coffee bitterness and milk chocolate flavor. A touch of a hopped note. A nice light drinkable stout. Nice roasty characteristic. Highly drinkable while still being creamy enough. Good stuff.

bottle. Poured black with a dense brown head. Aroma is sweet and roasty. Full body with an oily mouthfeel and a lingering bitter finsh. Flavour of heavily roasted malt, smokey with coffee notes and some molasses. Just what i needed during the cold snap.

Black with a medium tan head. Aroma is light coffee. Flavor is mildly sweet coffee with a bittersweet finish.

Wife: 4.3

Dark in color with a tan-colored head that disappears quickly with spotty lacing. Strong coffee aroma. It taste like the old kettle coffee with the coffee grains that find there way into the cup itself. To strong of a coffee taste for me. Average carbonation with a smooth finish. Again it was to strong of a coffee taste for me.

12oz bottle from Mitsuyas in Asagaya, Tokyo. Poured into a stemmed tulip. Deep brownish black color with beautiful tan head. Dark roasted coffee and malts on the nose. Flavor is overly coffee with hints of malt to balance out the coffee bitterness. Hops shine through with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Really well-balanced stout.
Silky black with semi creamy mocha colored head. They surely delivered on the coffee part of the stout. Coffee comes off bitter and roasted. Its a good beer.

Rated on 02-08-2015 (Bottle) This beer pours a small tan head that mostly diminishes, mostly opaque dark brown body, fast rising carbonation observed, and a fair amount of lacing. This beers aroma is roasted malt, rich, roasted coffee. The flavor is moderately bitter, roasted malt, roasted coffee, and a suggestion of fruit. The mouthfeel is lively and this beer is medium bodied. A very quaffable stout and one for coffee drinkers.

This bottled brew from a grocery store poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that were very long lasting and left behind a no visible carbonation opaque black brown colored body and an excellent lacing. . The sharp crisp mouth feel was weakly tingly at the start mediumly tingly at the finish with a lingering dark malt aftertaste. The nice flavor contained notes of roasted malt toffee toasted malt coffee brown malt and dark malt. Delicious and one I would certainly like to have again.
12 oz bottle. Black with an average beige head. Aroma is heavy in roasted malts with coffee, yeast, and light smoke. Taste is of roasted malt, coffee, cocoa powder, lightly burnt toast. Dry.

Bottle.  Packaged on:  11/12/14.  Pours a deep mahogany with a nicely sized mocha head.  Rich roasted coffee, caramel, chocolate, sour milk, and some earthy grains dominate the aroma.  Medium-bodied and kinda smooth on the way down.  Caramel and chocolate are present upfront in the taste.  Roasted coffee, dark chocolate, and earthy grains finish things off.  A hoppy presence underneath.  A bittersweet end.  Solid.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark almost black with medium thick, tan head. Aroma of roasted coffee, slight vanilla and strong roasted malts. Flavors of coffee, roast malts, chocolate, vanilla, slight hop balance. Taste is mostly bitter. Slightly thin but easy to drink with bitter and coffee finish.

not that different from Sierra Nevadas regular stout, but that isnt a bad thing. It pours dark brown the black, the head is thin. The aroma is like Sierra Nevada stout, but heavier on the coffee grounds quality, plus some anise. It smells great. The coffee in the flavor mostly comes through in the aftertaste, on the exhale. This is a beer I like more with each sip, and I was reluctant to finish the last of the three in the mixed twelve pack. I hated to see it go.

Pours black with thick foamy head. Strong coffee aroma with hints of caramel and chocolate. Pretty straightforward, not very complex. Pleasant roasty taste, not burnt like some others. A bit thin but nice lacing. Bitter finish.

Bottle from Taniguchi. Big coffee nose, with chocolate, some caramel, and a touch of citrus hop. Pitch black, shiny, with a huge, tan, pillowy head. Somewhat sweet and creamy, coffee and chocolate, some caramel, and a very bitter finish, roast and hop and coffee. A bit thin. Quite tangy as well. Decent, but not so special, and a bit harsh.

Bottle from 12 pack sampler. Coffee in the nose, but not your typical coffee beer aroma, more like the sweet smell of freshly brewed coffee. Nearly opaque body with hues of red visible when held up against light. Thin light brown head. Flavor is a wonderful, perfectly balanced, moderately hopped goodness. I'm not really that ena mores with very many coffee beers but this is an exception. I saw this beer as one of Clown Shoes' favorite beers of 2014 and I can see why. Really yummy.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2016 Bottle. Pours dark almost black brown. Thick brown head. Aroma is fresh coffee, toast, roasted malts and a hint of chocolate. Taste is dark coffee with roasted malt and dark chocolate. Heavy body, medium carbonation. Thanks for the trade JB.
I just had on tap at the Old Toad with JB and its still good,

I like that SN is making more styles these days and this beer is typical of them: rock solid classic beer styles with moderate embellishments (in this case coffee), if any. This is a great stout with moderate coffee aroma and flavors. A touch of sweetness up front and a nice bitter, but not overly bitter, finish. Fantastic beer.
Bottle. Black beer with a brown head. Coffee aroma. Caramel and coffee flavor with backing PNW hops. Medium bodied. Caramel and coffee linger with pine and light grapefruit.

On tap, poured a black hue w/ frothy light tan head. Moderate coffee aroma. Initial taste is moderate sweet w/ a moderate bitter finish. Tastes are dark roast coffee, bittersweet chocolate, dark bread, and roasted malts. Full bodied and creamy mouthfeel.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

bottle - Pours near black with a lasting tan head. It has a nice aroma of dark roast malt and coffee. The flavor is similar and well balanced. The coffee comes through really well and the base stout is a very good one.

Holy heck this stout is heavy on the coffee! This one has got to have THE most coffee-like flavors I have ever tasted in one bottle. The beer poured a black color with a light brown head. The head left some really nice, sticky lacing around the inside of the glass. The nose is full of coffee, chocolate, caramel, roasted bread, light cream and some bitter hops. The body is fairly thick and strong. This will make for a good brew on cold winters evening. As I mentioned, the flavors are heavy on the coffee beans, with notes of espresso, chocolate, cream, bitter hops, sweet and roasted malts, a hint of caramel and burnt bread. The finish is roasted, strong and begs you to take another sip. This is a really great stout!

12 fl oz bottle via Piscator34. Pours an opaque dark brown with a big mocha coloured head. Aromas of roasted coffee, chocolate, and a little black licorice. Coffee becomes more prominent as the beer warms. Tastes are coffee and cocoa. Medium body, oily texture, medium to longish bitter finish. This is a nice beverage.

Black pour with a foamy, tan head. The aroma has chocolate and mild coffee. It has a full body with creamy texture and average carbonation. The taste is roasted with dark chocolate and coffee notes especially in the finish.

Bottle (12 oz). Bought @ Craft Beer Cellar Waterbury.

Appearance: Black with a medium brown head and good lacing. 

Aroma: Massive coffee presence along light sweetness, vegetal notes and light fruitiness.

Taste: Strong coffee/roasted presence, light sweetness, caramel, light/moderate fruitiness, vegetal notes and moderate bitterness.

Palate: Medium body. Medium carbonation. Silky mouthfeel. Moderately lasting coffee bitterness finish.

Overall: Impressive Stout. It packs a lot of flavors with beautiful coffee features. Balance is pretty good. Drinkabiliy isnt bad either. Tasty stuff.

12oz bottle via winter pack from Bayville Spirits. Poured black with a creamy light tan head. Aroma of rich espresso powder, milk chocolate, and dark malts. Taste is much the same with an earthy bitterness, and vanilla beans in the finish. Solid

Sierra Nevada Coffee Stout 6.2% pours a jet black into a snifter with a rusty tan head. The nose is rally savoury like the porter with a big roasty coffee bean character to it. Motor oil viscosity with a bit of a thin dry finish the taste is roasty, oyster, coffee and light cream - its pretty damn nice. Definitely a savoury coffee stout but fairly well balanced. Possibly the best out of the 4 then again this is the style that is most likely to hold up well to the vagaries of transportation as well. Good.

Bottle from the Snowpack sampler. Perfectly black body with a light tan head that was thin but long lasting. A massive medium roast coffee nose. Along with the coffee are hints of green grass and cocoa. The body is silky smooth, almost greasy slick in the mouth. Flavors of a medium roast coffee are apparent along with bits bread crust. The finish has pleasing raisins and roast. Well balanced with only hints of astringency. I find that most coffee beers are loaded with astringent sourness and this one only has traces on the back end. Restrained and balanced, this one is a pleasant winner.

Continuing the nights theme... Bottle, nice tan head. Smooth coffee, roast, earthy, mocha, grassy, and bready. Hints of raisin and hazelnut too. The body of this coffee beer is far better than the two before it. Nice brew.
Bottle at Jans party - final one of Austins week ... Great roasty nose and flavor. Some caramel. 15.3

Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, dark fruit, and chocolate. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, hops, and roasted malt. Medium mouthfeel. Didnt think my rating would be so high, but this one was really good.
This is more than coffee-like, it is literally coffee - with a splash of bitter beer. Not being a coffee-drinker, this was still somewhat appealing.

Drank from a bottle thank you John! This is my first Sierra Nevada rating on this site (I rated a crap load with" beer seek" on facebook). Smells chocolately with a slight hint of coffee. I know this coffee stout is nice and jet black. Taste of deep rich coffee, roasted malts, chocolate, the best is that it has a nice bitterness that isnt overly dry but leaves yo salivating for more. I have not had a Sierra in a lot of time due to preconceived notion of them being uncontollably hoppy.

Ratings are correct below, but I changed some marks above to make the final rating as correct as possible with Beer Advocates "revamped" system. The 4.15 overall rating is correct.

Type: 12-oz. bottle

Price: $13.99 for a variety pack

Poured a pitch black color with three fingers of dark khaki, frothy tan. Good amount of layered, foamy lacing on the sides of the glass. Thick foamy retention on the top all the way down. (Sight - 3.75)

Smelled roasty coffee malts, dark chocolate, smoky fire, dark caramel, toffee, sweet espresso, roasted nuts and dark fudge. (Smell - 4.25)

Tasted similar to the nose. Dark chocolate, roasted coffee beans, caramel, toffee, roasted nuttiness, smoky fire, burnt marshmallow, espresso, fudge, dark fruit, maybe plum? (Taste - 4.13)

Full body. Creamy texture. Average carbonation. Long, warming finish. (Feel - 4.25)

This was just a really good coffee stout. Would have it again for sure. (Overall - 4.13)

4.15 93 A-
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2016 Black with a creamy resilient tan head. Smooth body. Medium full. Aroma of coffee, roasted malts, and dark chocolate. Roasty coffee taste; moderately bitter. Nice.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2015 Coffee.


Smells of coffee, looks of coffee, tastes of coffee. Is this beer?

Seriously though, its a bit much. I love coffee and coffee stouts, but this flavor-added thing is a little crazy. Ill revisit next winter though!

Bottle. Pours dark brown, with a light brown head. Aroma is coffee, roasted malt, dark fruit, and chocolate. Flavor is coffee, chocolate, hops, and roasted malt. Body is medium to thin. Long, sightly bitter finish.
Bottle from Santa. Rich dark flavors meld well w/slight coffee taste. Well balanced, drinkable beer.
coffee, roasty, smoke, spruce, woody, brown, cloudy, frothy, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, salty, medium body, average carbonation, bitter,
Bottle, black pour, tan head, nose and taste are super duper coffee, some faint vanilla in the background, oh yeah
Nice rich malt. Chocolate and coffee some spice and a nice balancing bitter. Straightforward and drinkable.

12oz bottle, from Brunos in LG. Pours a jet black color with a tan head and some lacing. Aroma is roasty, coffee, some bittersweet chocolate. Medium on the palate with creamy carbonation. Flavor is sweet, malty, roasty, coffee, chocolate, with a light bitter coffee finish.

Fresh bottle for beer fridge....part of a holiday 12 pack from SN....very nice.

Bold malty / coffee nose and taste from a black black beer...tan head.

Taste include hints of dark and bittersweet chocolate...maybe a bit of cherry....

Very tasty....wish it was a regular on the SN line

Bottle courtesy of piscator34- pours the usual ebony, frothy mocha head. vibrant lacing. Nose- lively medium roast coffee, powdered chocolate, licorice. Taste- zippy carbonation, strong coffee, dark chocolate fudge, not overly bitter, nor sweet. very well balanced. very drinkable

Coffee adds nice accents to this stout, more dark chocolate than coffee. Dry bitter finish, not overwhelming, light roastiness, semi sweet chocolate. Lighter body than the norm, but very smooth and silky.

12 oz Bottle. Tasted on 12/20/14. Beer from Moore Liquor. Bottle date 11/3/14. Pours to a deep black color with minimal head. Aroma is roasty & full of coffee. Taste is smooth with good body & great balance of enough coffee but not too overwhelming. Great coffee stout.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Black pour with a tall, frothy tan head. Big roasted malt and coffee notes with dark chocolate and burnt caramel as well. Taste is big roasted malt, dark, oily coffee beans, burnt caramel, bittersweet dark chocolate and burnt chocolate chip cookies. Body is medium with a moderate, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, burnt caramel and burnt cookies.

12 oz bottle- Pours mostly black with a nice creamy tan head and nice lacing, like all Sierra Nevada beers beautiful beer. The aroma is strong coffee, high quality espresso beans, some cream. The taste is roasted coffee beans, chocolate malt, hops are fairly prominent. Body is a bit more thin than I would like, its more like a coffee porter than a coffee stout. Aroma was by far the best part of this beer, still solid all around.
Overall, this wasnt nearly as heavy or coffee-laden as I expected, which is a good thing. Im not much a coffee beer guy but this was decent.
Ruby tinted dark brown pour. Big creamy tan head. Plenty of lacing. Big fruity coffee nose. Big coffee up front with some pepper following. Notes of chocolate. Nice.

Poured a deep tan, pillowed head. Color is black and even looks like it has coffee in it. Awesome lacing. The nose has awesome roasted coffee notes. Makes me wonder what coffee they used. Smokey notes as well as chocolate and roasted malts remind me of chocolate covered coffee beans. Medium body and creamy on the palate and tastes like chocolate covered coffee beans as well. Finishes with some ash and there's a little leafy hops buried in there. At only 6.2%, this is packed with flavor. Winner winner energy dinner. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle. Barely translucent deep brown color, khaki head with good lace on the glass. Roasted coffee flavor (duh) with some fruit notes in the finish, along with a nice happiness that I wasnt really expecting. Quite good.

Pours dark almost black brown. Thick brown head. Smell is fresh coffee groudns, roasted malts and a hint of chocolate. Taste is dark coffee with roasted malt and dark chocolate shavings. Heavy body, medium carbonation.

Aroma is fresh coffee, roasted malt. Appearance is black, light brown head. Taste is coffee, somewhat light, roasted malt. Mouthfeel is light but full-bodied, decent carbonation. Overall...very nice as always.

Pour is dark, dark brown. Khaki head, very nice lacing. Aroma is (you guessed it!) coffee, with burnt malts added in for good measure. Taste is bitter coffee with a nice hop bite. Medium bodied. No sweetness in this one. All bitterness. Its ok.

Dark coffee appearance with thin head. Initial espresso aroma then subtle hint of alcohol. Rich, up front, iced coffee flavor, alcohol, good bit of carbonation for a stout. Thin texture, mild finish with coffee flavor trailing off quickly.
Bottle. Dark brown pour with a tan head. Dark roasted coffee, roasted malt and a bit of dark fruit in the aroma and taste. Just as advertised.

12oz bottle shared at the holiday tasting 
Black with a small tan head, some lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and coffee. Taste of roasted malts, coffee and ashy 
Good

DATE TASTED: November 21, 2014... GLASSWARE: Samuel Smith pint... OCCASION: Cavs/Wiz:trying this new Cavs thing again... APPEARANCE: relatively creamy, rocky brown head; black-as-midnight body; lacing is darn near Brussels ... AROMA: roasted malty espresso punch! thick, musty and toasty--undoubtedly chocolaty and peaty... PALATE:thick as molasses, yet smooth on the tongue; finish is appreciable...TASTE: a rum-like warmth hits with a luscious coffee bean intensity; secondary notes of cola ... OVERALL: a confident, late-night wake-up of a stout that shakes the tastebuds ever-so-slightly; nice to see Sierra get into the types of micro styles they set in motion decades ago... their winter pack approaches a party must-have with this one...
12oz bottle in Seattle. Thanks Trev for the to-go bottle :) Dark beer, good head. Sweet roasty coffee. Solid drinker, rich body, balanced, coffee roast. Tasty.

12oz bottle pours with a nice dark body that supports a mocha colored head. The aroma offers up yummy inviting earthy coffee, some chocolate and dark roasted malts. I like. The taste delivers dark and roasty and earthy coffee goodness blended into some pleasing chocolate notes and then more earthy coffee and slivers of dark roasted malts into the finish. Very nice coffee stout.
Poured from a bottle it is dark brown with a slight head. The aroma is coffee and the taste is a strong espresso with a delicious coffee after taste
From a 12 oz bottle shared at home. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of expresso beans. Flavors of coffee. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Bitter roast finish. Nice.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine, Chesapeake, VA. Very dark brown pour with a rich and frothy khaki head. Aroma of roasted espresso and star anise. Very well-integrated taste of rich coffee with expected yet understated notes of chocolate, dark fruit, and caramel. A nicely done and bold coffee stout.

Once it warmed up a little it really opened up. Tons of the coffee you should expect with a nice smoothness that really made me want another one. Not much of a head on it but still nice roasty and a touch of bitter chocolate.

Moderate coffee aroma, with hints of dark fruit. Pours an opaque black with a thin tan head. The cold brewed coffee notes are there, which helps to leave out the astringency. Theres a bit more sweetness in this then I prefer in my coffee stouts, but its not cloying. Nice lingering coffee notes on the finish. Moderate body, and a nice sipper.
Pours a jet black with thin off-white head and thick lacing. Rich aromas coffee beans and roasted malts. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, hints of chocolate, slight bitterness. A wonderful coffee stout.

12oz bottle. Attractive beige head on top of an oily black-brown body. Roasty coffee, chocolate tones. True to style, well executed. Not the most exciting offering, a little light on the hops for Sierra Nevada. Still a solid beer.

Pours a dark brown w/ a tan head that films out. Faint aroma: coffee. Flavor is way off balance; all bitter and sour. All the coffee flavor is everything that is bad about a stale cup of coffee. May be the worst coffee beer I have had. Wont drink again.

Bottle. Black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of dark roast coffee with cream, chocolate, and vanilla. Balanced in the mouth between the coffee, chocolate, pale malt, and caramel notes. Medium bodied with a nice savory espresso bitterness on the finish. Nothing over-the-top, but everything in its right place.
12oz bottle. Black pour with a small tan head and a little bubbly retention. Aroma of roasted malt and coffee. Tastes are bitter acidic coffee, little smoke, earthy, chocolate. Nice, straightforward.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a tan head. Aroma of roasty coffee, vanilla, and dark cocoa. Roasty coffee flavor, a bit ashen, dark chocolate touches. Seem to be some hoppy touches hiding in there as well. Quite good.
12 oz bottle, thanks brenn79. Nearly opaque dark brown with red edges; tan head with great retention. Strong coffee nose, roasty. Coffee, roast, in flavor, light bitterness. Great coffee beer.
From the bottle. Chocolate, roast, toffee, and bitterness in the aroma. Taste is dark chocolate with bitter coffee and lingering bitterness. Clean mouthfeel. Excellent.
Dark tan head. Great lacing. Black as coffee. Strong ground coffee aroma. Chocolate and coffee flavor with an afterthought of bitterness. Tastes like coffee mixed with beer, and I love it!

Dare I say the poor mans breakfast stout? It pours essentially black w/ a foamy head & spotty lacing. The aroma is of dark malt, chocolate, & coffee. The taste is all of the above & pretty complex for the abv. The palate is a touch thin but theres not much else to knock here. This is one fine stout!
Bottle. Strong coffee and toffee malt aroma. Black with small tan head. Sweet creamy coffee and malt flavor with a moderately bitter herbal coffee ground finish. Very tasty.

Bottle:
Ruby-black with a thick, dark tan head.
Dark chocolate, coffee, roast aroma.
Taste is mildly ashy coffee malt, dark chocolate.
A bit of dark berry notes.
Very good.

12 oz bottle, bottled 10/28/14. Pours dark brown with a medium creamy tan head that goes to a thin film and laces the glass.

The aroma is sweet lactic chocolate with some acidic burnt roast.

The flavor is sweet lactic chocolate with some burnt roast in the finish. i dont get much coffee. The mouthfeel is medium bodied with smooth carbonation.

Overall, lots of lactose and burnt roast, not much coffee.
Dec. 3, 2014/12 oz. bottle in shaker glass. Black as night; one-finger tan head with proud lacing. Roasty and complex. Extended, bitter finish with notes of dark chocolate. A winner.

Black short head some lace. Roast coffee aroma with chocolate notes,dark berries or fruity yeast esters? Taste is roast chocolate coffee, dark berry, musty earthy roast/ or hops. A lot of berry undertones but I get that a lot in lots of stouts I notice. More chocolaty and coffee altogether than roast, pretty smooth though with some mild sharp tang and acidity. Pretty nice coffee in it but a bit day old almost slightly. I love coffee but it falls a little short in what good coffee aromas I love. Nothing to complain about though. Not shure if coffee may act like hops in beer and loose its good character with age, never had an aged coffee stout but sounds good.

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2014 12 ounce bottle pours a deep black color with a huge tan foamy head that lasts for quite a long time. Nice lacing on the glass. Nice aroma of coffee and dark chocolate. Very nice and flavorful huge coffee taste. Medium mouth feel. Very nice flavorful stout.

Dark chocolate brown, big cardboard-brown head. 

Plums and dates in the nose. with a dusty mocha/coffee component as a base. Has a little bit of a boozy burn in the nostrils as well. Tremendous and complex: stone fruit sweetness with a dry cereal grain base. Nutty later.

The first flavor is cold, burnt coffee: that wave of bitterness just hits the esophagus just so. There is a slight woody hop character that is totally unexpected and yet fits perfectly.

Slick feel, with a dry, dusty finish. This one is a winner: a coffee stout with beautiful plum/date flavors to balance. All coffee stouts should be so good.
Very dark and heavy with a strong coffee aroma. A nice blend of caramel and coffee that leaves you striving for more.
Pours black with tan head. Aroma is Coffee. A little more heavy and bitter than I expected, its pretty good. Coffee, caramel, very roasty. Good.

Pours black with some roasted grains in the nose. Medium body with lots of flavor and a little coffee. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a good black with a small beige head that leaves good lacing. Nose is of coffee, coffee-mate, burnt toasts. Taste is moderately sweet but also quite bitter from all the roasted malt. Flavors are of coffee, light green hops and while there is no ash (good) there is a really light green pepper presence. Body is medium-full and carbonation toned down. Mouthfeel is lightly sticky. Never harsh. Overall a nice coffe stout, not to Pêché Mortels level but then again it isnt an imperial stout either. Nice!

Poured very thick and dark from 12 oz. bottle. Nice lingering off-white head. Strong aroma of concentrated coffee, similar to cold brew. Hints of cocoa and earthy roasted nuts. Well balanced taste with an initial blast of espresso then bitter sweet notes of dark chocolate finished with caramel. Overall, a very good value.

Solid coffee stout. HUGE coffee aroma is really nice. Flavor almost matches, but has a hint of vegetal young coffee and maaaaybe just a touch too much bitterness. But thats nitpicking. This is a solid beer on the cheap. Id probably get again if its ever sold on its own.

12 ounce bottle from the Snow Pack opened 11/7/14. Pours a clear very dark brown with a large foamy brown head. Good head retention. Rich coffee notes emanate from a few feet away. Aroma of roasted malts, coffee, dark chocolate, hints of tobacco. The taste is bitter roast, bitter coffee, chocolate, tobacco. Medium bodied, lingering bitterness, moderate carbonation.

From a bottle shared by Joe. Pours very dark brown with a bubbly beige head. Tastes like dry roasted malt, burnt coffee, toast, light smoke and light molasses. Light body and low carbonation. Smells like burnt coffee, burnt toast, toasted malt, light ash and light smoke.

Bottle. Pours deep, dark brown with creamy beige head. Aroma is coffee, dark chocolate, roasted malts, some earthiness and light prunes. Flavor is dry roast malt base, some coffee notes, some dark fruit notes, and some light earthy bitterness. Medium body and carbonation.

This strikes me as really hoppy for a coffee beer but it works. Its dark brown with a fine bubbled gray head. Its coffee aroma is complimented by citrus fruit. Texture is creamy with slight punctuation from carbonation. Hop bitterness mingles nicely with fresh coffee flavor. A very mild tartness brings out a bit of dried fruit character. This is a very well put together beer with good solid flavors that fit together well.

Embouteillée le 3 novembre 2014. Une présentation quasi impeccable. Solides arômes de café de haute qualité, de grains lourdement torréfiés et même brûlés avec des notes de chocolat presque pur. Superbes saveurs de café bien serré, de chocolat très noir, de caramel noirci et de torréfaction bien léchées par une douce mais tranquille entité. Robuste mais hautement intelligent. Corps de moyenne densité avec un bon apport de bulles. Belle texture huileuse. Finale amère, pleine de café épicé mais aussi caramélisée et fruitée. Très bon stout au café. Je pense que Sierra Nevada ne peut rien rater. Vivement dautres bouteilles de ce truc si délicieux.
Got in the winter 12 pack, pours the part. Massive black coffee taste and nose. Mild astringency but over all a solid coffee stout.

12oz bottle via mix 12pack. Poured an all right looking deep black medium density body under a larger dark beige head. Aroma was cold pressed coffee, burnt malts, cream. Medium body with average carbonation and a lingering coffee aftertaste. Flavor was burnt malts, dark toast and coffee. Definitely prefer FBS to this.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with tan head. Nose and taste are a lot of coffee with a little chocolate.

12oz bottle poured into a Shaker at 41°. Color is black with good carbonation and a tight brown head. Aroma is sweet deeply roasted coffee. It has a full body with a creamy mouth feel. Flavor is deep roasted almost smoky coffee then a note of bittersweet chocolate and just a faint hint of sweet shows giving off a fruit note. After taste is dry and bitter leaving it feel like black coffee. Overall its a very well done stout with bold coffee flavors.

11/26/14. 12oz bottle from the SN winter mix 12pk. Dark pour, basically black, perhaps dark brown and rubies under the light, under a really nice tan head that cuts in half, sticks, and almost coats the glass in lacing. Wow. Bold coffee aroma, heavily roasted, bittersweet dark chocolate, some dark fruitiness. Coffee in the flavor as well, of course, lightly acidic, roasty, dark chocolate, licorice, more dark fruitiness. Very smooth, creamy mouthfeel. Not bad!

What a nice looker. I really admired the head and color swirls as I poured this. Dark, tan, multicolored. Thick head. Nose was a bit dampened perhaps by being a bit too chilled, perhaps by the voluminous head. Mostly got bittersweet chocolate. Taste is a bit of coffee and anise, with a hoppy gritty presence thoughout. Dry dark finish. Clean mouthfeel.
Bottle from bhensonb. Pours near black with a rich tan head and a coffee and treacle aroma. There is a hearty bitter chocolate, dark molasses and coffee flavor with a dry finish. A nice brew.

Bought the 12 pack and drank the 3 of these while frying fish. Fun times. So with coffee beers there tends to be 2 extremes and this one falls somewhere in the middle. There are those coffee porters/stouts that are all cold coffee flavor with little malt backbone or any depth at all, thin and empty, and I usually hate them all. And then there are those that are big on dark chewy malts and the coffee is there more as a complementary flavor than the focus. I generally love these. This beer is somewhere in the middle. It has plenty of body and dark roast and chocolate malt, feels pretty similar to their standard stout. But this one also has a huge coffee component, very strong coffee aroma and fairly prominent coffee flavor too. So I guess I like this one about as much as somewhere halfway between the thin coffee beers I hate and the heavy coffee beers I love. Which is just a long winded way of saying I liked it.
